word.entryDescription: to leave a small vehicle such as a bicycle, or to leave a large vehicle such as a bus, train or plane
word.entryExample: When do they get off the underground train?

word.entryDescription: to move onto a small vehicle such as a bicycle, or to move onto a large vehicle such as a bus, train or plane
word.entryExample: You have to check in and get your boarding card before you get on the plane.
So, how did you get on Saturday?

word.entryDescription: to have a friendly relationship with someone
word.entryExample: Kate is jealous that Emma and Harry get on with each other so well.

word.entryDescription: to leave a place or to avoid doing something you are expected to do
word.entryExample: I need to get out of here now or else they will find me.

word.entryDescription: to take action so that something unwanted or unpleasant is no longer present
word.entryExample: Don't get rid of plastic bottles in general rubbish.

word.entryDescription: to arrive somewhere
word.entryExample: Go straight on until you get to a big road, and then turn left.

word.entryDescription: to take off your clothes
word.entryExample: I get undressed and change into my pyjamas before I go to bed at night.

word.entryDescription: to leave your bed after you wake up
word.entryExample: What time do you get up at the weekend?

word.entryDescription: to do physical work
word.entryExample: Let's get our hands dirty and do some gardening.

word.entryDescription: the car that criminals use when escaping, for example from a place they have robbed
word.entryExample: The police spotted the bank robbers' getaway car on the motorway and chased them to the very city centre.

word.entryDescription: a town where most people have left
word.entryExample: This is nothing more than a ghost town with no future prospects.

word.entryDescription: a place, e.g. in a museum, where you can buy souvenirs
word.entryExample: There's a gift shop near the zoo.

word.entryDescription: a unit for measuring computer information, equal to 1,024 megabytes
word.entryExample: My computer has 220 gigabytes and it's all packed. How did this happen?

word.entryDescription: a tall African animal with a very long neck and legs
word.entryExample: Giraffes have long necks.

word.entryDescription: to put something into someone's hands
word.entryExample: My dad often gives my mum flowers.

word.entryDescription: to accept that you are defeated in a fight, competition etc
word.entryExample: Rebecca is extra bad-tempered at the moment, because she is trying to do without cigarettes. She is determined not to give in.

word.entryDescription: to stop doing something that you do regularly, such as an unhealthy habit, an activity, etc
word.entryExample: Give up sugary drinks and all the unnecessary sweet snacks you eat during the day.

word.entryDescription: a large mass of ice which moves slowly down a valley
word.entryExample: That's the glacier on Mount Kilimanjaro.

word.entryDescription: a small container made of glass used for drinking
word.entryExample: Two glasses of lemonade, please.

word.entryDescription: made or consisting of glass
word.entryExample: The water container must not be glass.

word.entryDescription: something people wear over their eyes to help them see
word.entryExample: Where are my glasses?

word.entryDescription: past simple form of 'glimmer' – to shine with a weak or unsteady light
word.entryExample: The lights of the capital glimmered and shimmered into focus on the horizon.

word.entryDescription: the slow increase of average world temperatures believed to be the result of pollution and human activity
word.entryExample: The increase in greenhouse gases has caused global warming and a rise in sea levels.

word.entryDescription: plural of 'glove' – something you wear on your hands to protect them or keep them warm
word.entryExample: She needs gloves because it's cold.

word.entryDescription: a sticky substance used to join things together
word.entryExample: You need to use glue to put this plane together.

word.entryDescription: to walk or move to a place
word.entryExample: Let's go to the park and play football.

word.entryDescription: to take a car trip somewhere nice
word.entryExample: We went for a drive to the museum yesterday.

word.entryDescription: to choose something as a study subject or career
word.entryExample: Davis wants to go in for a job in the technology industry when he graduates.

word.entryDescription: to become bad and unfit to eat
word.entryExample: 'Why does food go off?' 'It's because of the bacteria'.

word.entryDescription: use the Internet
word.entryExample: Can I use the computer now? I need to go online and pay the bills.

word.entryDescription: to leave home for a short time, especially to do something entertaining
word.entryExample: Let's go out for dinner.

word.entryDescription: spend time with a boyfriend / girlfriend
word.entryExample: Emma and Harry aren't going out with each other. They are just friends.

word.entryDescription: take a boat or yacht and sail on water
word.entryExample: Why don't we go sailing on Ontario at the weekend?

word.entryDescription: to examine or search something very carefully
word.entryExample: The lawyer went through all the documents but couldn't find any evidence to her advantage.

word.entryDescription: to get inside your bed so you can sleep
word.entryExample: I'm going to bed, I'm very tired.

word.entryDescription: to go to a place where children learn
word.entryExample: We go to Green Wood School.

word.entryDescription: to stop being awake and start sleeping
word.entryExample: Go to sleep now, it's very late!

word.entryDescription: to walk or move to a place that is higher than where you are
word.entryExample: Let's go up that hill and look at the city from above.

word.entryDescription: look attractive when worn together
word.entryExample: These sandals don’t go well with this dress.

word.entryDescription: to exist with something, look or taste good with one another
word.entryExample: Water goes with any meal.

word.entryDescription: when you score a goal in football, you succeed in kicking a ball into the net
word.entryExample: Alex scores a goal!

word.entryDescription: an animal like a sheep but with straight fur and often horns, which lives on mountains or on farms
word.entryExample: Are there a lot of goats on the farm?

word.entryDescription: third person singular of 'go' – to move or travel to a place
word.entryExample: He goes to school in London.

word.entryDescription: a valuable yellow metal
word.entryExample: This watch is made of gold.

word.entryDescription: made of or the colour of gold
word.entryExample: I gave her a gold ring.

word.entryDescription: made of or the colour of gold
word.entryExample: Two of our camps are beside a golden, sandy beach.

word.entryDescription: nice or enjoyable
word.entryExample: Have a good time at the party!

word.entryDescription: something you say to greet somebody in the afternoon
word.entryExample: Good afternoon, Ms Black! What a lovely day!

word.entryDescription: able to do something well
word.entryExample: Are you good at singing?
